title: 115_s2074
content: In this Act, the definitions include the Board as the Stutsman County Park Board in Jamestown, North Dakota, the game and fish headquarters as depicted on the map, the Jamestown Reservoir constructed under the Flood Control Act of 1944, and the Management Agreement between the United States of America and Stutsman County Park Board. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to the Management, Development, Operation, and Maintenance of Recreation and Related Improvements and Facilities at Jamestown Reservoir in Stutsman County, North Dakota. Key terms defined include Map, Permitted cabin land, Property, Recreation land, and Secretary. The Secretary will convey recreation land and permitted cabin land to Stutsman County Park Board at no cost within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The Board will pay for all survey and administrative costs for title transfers of the conveyed land. The recreation land will be managed for public access, fish and wildlife habitat, and to preserve its natural character. The Board will manage permitted cabin land for existing cabins or recreational residences, or for recreation land management purposes. Haying and grazing on recreation land may continue as authorized under existing contracts. If land conveyed under specific requirements is used inconsistently, it may revert to the United States. The sale of permitted cabin land must be at fair market value, excluding improvements made by the permit holder. The Board must pay any proceeds exceeding sale costs to the Secretary for permitted cabin land sales. Amounts paid for land conveyance under this Act will fund Jamestown Dam activities. The Secretary will convey Game and Fish Headquarters to the State within 5 years of the Act's enactment. The United States will convey the game and fish headquarters to the State with the condition that it continues to be used for similar purposes. If the land is used inconsistently, it may revert back to the United States. Each conveyance will be subject to existing rights and operational requirements of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Program. The conveyance of land includes reservations such as flowage easements, mineral rights, permits, and deed restrictions for the Jamestown Reservoir. Applicable easements for vehicular access are also granted. The United States is not liable for flood damage to properties with permits, except for damages caused by the US before the enactment of the Act. Temporary flooding or damage is not considered a taking by the US. SEC. 5. INTERIM REQUIREMENTS: Management Agreement provisions and permits remain in effect until property conveyance under the Act. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
